headline.print_headline: Competition Is Healthy for Governments, Too
headline.seo: Competition Is Good for Governments, Too - Economic View
headline.main: Competition Is Healthy for Governments, Too

docs.snippet: Companies, as well as people, can vote with their feet if they don’t like the way their state or local government is treating them....
docs.abstract: N Gregory Mankiw Economic View column suggests that competition among governments--for population or investment capital--mirrors disparate viewpoints between liberals and conservatives about the role of government; says conservatives embrace government competition, while liberals have good reason to worry about it because of their expansive view of the role of public policy; holds elections are about which view voters find more compelling.
docs.lead_paragraph: Companies, as well as people, can vote with their feet if they don’t like the way their state or local government is treating them.

headline.seo: Path, FamilyLeaf and Pair, Small-by-Design Social Networks

docs.snippet: On Path, FamilyLeaf and Pair, users can post information without fear of sharing with the wrong people....
docs.abstract: Randall Stross Digital Domain column observes social network start-ups are offering sharing that is intimate by design; notes on newer networks like Path, FamilyLeaf and Pair, users can post information without fear of sharing with the wrong people, as they offer a range of constraints.
docs.lead_paragraph: On Path, FamilyLeaf and Pair, users can post information without fear of sharing with the wrong people.

docs.lead_paragraph: Pommel horse is the first, and the weakest, event the United States men’s Olympic gymnastics team will face when qualifying begins in London on July 28.

headline.print_headline: Duplicating Afghanistan From the Ground Up
headline.main: Duplicating Afghanistan From the Ground Up

docs.snippet: Military officials send recruits from across the country to Central California because it shares many agroclimatic characteristics with Afghanistan....

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
keywords.name: subject

docs.abstract: Program in Central California, financed by the Agriculture Department, aims to introduce American service members to the kinds of agriculture they are likely to encounter when they are deployed to Afghanistan; they study some basics of subsistence farming.
docs.lead_paragraph: Military officials send recruits from across the country to Central California because it shares many agroclimatic characteristics with Afghanistan.

headline.print_headline: Stores, and More, for Breast-Feeding Moms
headline.seo: For Breast-Feeding Moms, Stores and More
headline.main: Stores, and More, for Breast-Feeding Moms

docs.snippet: A small but growing niche of the baby-care industry offers not only the latest products, but also education and camaraderie....
docs.abstract: Nicole LaPorte Prototype column observes that a small but growing niche of the baby-care industry offers not only the latest products, but also education and camaraderie; highlights the Pump Station and Nurtury, a breast-feeding resource center and baby boutique in Santa Monica, Calif, which has managed to survive despite domination by megastores and other retailers of the $9.8 billion baby products industry.
docs.lead_paragraph: A small but growing niche of the baby-care industry offers not only the latest products, but also education and camaraderie.

headline.main: Mixing Golf and Ravioli With Business

docs.snippet: Annette Catino of QualCare Inc. says that business ties are built on the golf course, and that cooking a meal with other managers helps build a team....
docs.abstract: Adam Bryant Corner Office column features interview with QualCare Inc president and chief executive officer Annette Catino discussing her management techniques.
docs.lead_paragraph: Annette Catino of QualCare Inc. says that business ties are built on the golf course, and that cooking a meal with other managers helps build a team.

headline.print_headline: Unsolved Double Homicide Has Alaska Island on Edge

docs.lead_paragraph: Residents of Kodiak Island are unnerved by the fatal shootings of two people at a Coast Guard station.

headline.print_headline: Experts Split On Possibility Of Remains At Titanic Site
headline.seo: Titanic May Hold Passengers’ Remains, Officials Say
headline.main: Experts Split on Possibility of Remains at Titanic Site

docs.snippet: A federal ocean agency released an image that it says suggests that corpses are at the wreckage site, which officials are seeking to protect from salvagers....
docs.abstract: National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration releases an image that it says suggests that undiscovered corpses remain at the Titanic wreckage site; federal officials, who have long struggled to assert protective authority over the ship's resting place, say the site is a burial ground and thus should be accorded the respect of such and shielded from looters and artifact hunters; bold federal assertions are dividing Titanic experts, as most experienced divers say they doubt that bodies lie intact within unexplored compartments of the ship.
docs.lead_paragraph: A federal ocean agency released an image that it says suggests that corpses are at the wreckage site, which officials are seeking to protect from salvagers.

headline.print_headline: Choking Up Has Become a Lost Art in the Major League Batter’s Box

headline.main: Choking Up Has Become a Lost Art in the Major League Batter’s Box

docs.snippet: Barry Bonds choked up on the bat and wound up with 762 home runs, but many of today’s players say that choking up sacrifices power....

headline.print_headline: Moscow Protesters Take Their Show on the Road
headline.seo: Leaders of Rallies in Moscow Take Their Show on the Road
headline.main: Moscow Protesters Take Their Show on the Road

docs.snippet: The organizers staged their first major action outside the capital on Saturday, rallying about 1,500 people against alleged ballot fraud in the mayoral election of Astrakhan....
docs.abstract: Organizers of Moscow’s huge antigovernment street protests stage a rare major action outside the capital, rallying about 1,500 people against suspected ballot fraud in Astrakhan’s mayoral election; it is a modest turnout, showing that the antigovernment forces are still fumbling for a way forward and are so far unable to surmount public indifference and light a fire for political reform
docs.lead_paragraph: The organizers staged their first major action outside the capital on Saturday, rallying about 1,500 people against alleged ballot fraud in the mayoral election of Astrakhan.
